introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.description: Welcome to the enchanting world of Sri Lanka's indigenous animals. This page offers a glimpse into the rich biodiversity that graces the island nation. From majestic elephants to elusive leopards, Sri Lanka is home to a fascinating array of wildlife that captivates nature enthusiasts and conservationists alike.

content.title: Description
content.description: The sloth bear has a shaggy black coat and distinctive white V-shaped markings on its chest. It has long, curved claws adapted for climbing and feeding.

content.title: Behavior
content.description: Sloth bears are primarily nocturnal and have a unique habit of carrying cubs on their backs, providing protection.

content.title: Habitat
content.description: Found in various forested habitats, including dry and moist deciduous forests.

content.title: Description
content.description: Also known as the purple-faced leaf monkey, this primate species has a dark face with a purple hue. It has a long tail and is adapted for an arboreal lifestyle.

content.title: Habitat
content.description: Endemic to Sri Lanka, these langurs inhabit both lowland and montane rainforests.

content.title: Conservation
content.description: Faces threats from habitat loss and fragmentation. Conservation efforts focus on preserving their forest habitats.

content.title: Description
content.description: The Sri Lankan subspecies of spotted deer has a reddish-brown coat with white spots. Males have antlers.

content.title: Habitat
content.description: Found in a range of habitats, including grasslands, forests, and agricultural areas.

content.title: Conservation
content.description: While not currently endangered, habitat loss and hunting pose threats to their populations.
